solution_line_template: The number of CDs selling at $10 each at the store is {percentage_10_dollar_cds}*{total_cds} = <<{percentage_10_dollar_cds}*{total_cds}={num_10_dollar_cds}>>{num_10_dollar_cds}
This means the store sells {total_cds}-{num_10_dollar_cds} = <<{total_cds}-{num_10_dollar_cds}={num_5_dollar_cds}>>{num_5_dollar_cds} CDs at $5 each.

Prince bought {prince_bought_10_dollar_fraction}*{num_10_dollar_cds} = <<{prince_bought_10_dollar_fraction}*{num_10_dollar_cds}={prince_num_10_dollar_cds}>>{prince_num_10_dollar_cds} of the CDs selling at $10 each.

The total amount of money Prince paid for the {prince_num_10_dollar_cds} CDs selling at ${cost_10_dollar_cd} each is ${prince_num_10_dollar_cds}*{cost_10_dollar_cd} = $<<{prince_num_10_dollar_cds}*{cost_10_dollar_cd}={cost_prince_10_dollar_cds}>>{cost_prince_10_dollar_cds}

If he bought all the CDs selling at ${cost_5_dollar_cd} each, he paid a total of ${cost_5_dollar_cd}*{num_5_dollar_cds} = $<<{cost_5_dollar_cd}*{num_5_dollar_cds}={cost_prince_5_dollar_cds}>>{cost_prince_5_dollar_cds}
For all the CDs he bought, Prince spent ${cost_prince_5_dollar_cds}+${cost_prince_10_dollar_cds}= $<<{cost_prince_5_dollar_cds}+{cost_prince_10_dollar_cds}={total_spent}>>{total_spent}
